Award.AwardTitle: Build and Broaden: Advancing fundamental knowledge of social, behavioral, and economic responses to pandemics in minority communities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: COVID-19 provides an opportunity for Social, Behavioral and Economic science (SBE) researchers to develop and test new theories regarding sociocultural differences in responses to pandemics. Diverse perspectives in SBE research are essential to develop outcomes that benefit all members of society and promote the progress of science. Faculty at Minority Serving Institutions (MSI)â€™s have a unique perspective on COVID-19 and the potential to make significant contributions to fundamental research regarding minority community responses to pandemics. Northern Arizona University (NAU) has twenty statewide campuses, including the main Flagstaff mountain campus, and NAU-Yuma. NAU-Yuma is an MSI with 74% of students identifying as Hispanic/Latino. The NSF award will support a workshop at NAU-Flagstaff to advance fundamental knowledge of the social, behavioral and economic responses to pandemics in minority communities. <br/><br/>The goal of the workshop is to build capacity at NAU-Flagstaff and NAU-Yuma for SBE researchers to obtain competitive grant funding and broaden collaborations with faculty from an MSI in SBE research. The workshop will span two days and convene internationally recognized experts in behavioral and regional economics, diverse and early-career researchers in social, behavioral and economic sciences, and grant-writing specialists. The collaborative workshop format includes presentations from keynote speakers, expert led panels and small group breakout sessions. Participants will address two fundamental research questions: 1) What sociocultural factors determine behavioral responses to pandemics? and 2) How do changes in post-pandemic preferences impact tourism-dependent economies? The project deliverables include development of testable hypotheses that incorporate innovative research ideas with a diverse perspective and submission of competitive research proposals with MSI faculty collaborators.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Goals:

We proposed funding for a workshop at Northern Arizona University (NAU) to advance fundamental knowledge of the social, behavioral and economic responses to pandemics in minority communities. NAU is a Hispanic Serving Institution (HSI). The workshop convened experts in the areas of behavioral and regional economics and anthropology as experts and recruited diverse and early career researchers in the Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences (SBE) from NAU’s mountain and regional campuses as attendees. The goal of the workshop was to (1) build capacity at NAU for SBE researchers to obtain competitive grant funding and (2) broaden collaborations. The project deliverables included development of testable hypotheses that incorporate innovative research ideas with a diverse perspective and submission of competitive research proposals with HSI faculty collaborators.

(1)   Build capacity:

Four invited experts from relevant fields attended a workshop on May 18-19, 2022 at the NAU High Country Conference Center in Flagstaff, AZ. The workshop was designed to be collaborative and support relationship development. The first day consisted of invited presentations with extended time for discussion with four leading experts:

  • Dr. Robert Richardson, Professor of Economics at Michigan State University and Jefferson Science Fellow, led a presentation and Q&A session entitled, “Second-Order Impacts of the COVID-19 Pandemic.”
  • Levi Esquerra, Senior Vice President for Native American Advancement and Tribal Engagement at the University of Arizona, led a presentation and Q&A session entitled “Engaging minority communities in research.”  
  • Dr. Amy Ando, University Fellow at Resources for the Future and a leading researcher in economic valuation of environmental benefits and environmental justice at the University of Illinois, led a presentation and Q&A session entitled, “Developing a research agenda on environmental justice and COVID-19 in minority communities.
  • Dr. Lisa Hardy, Director of the Social Science Community Engagement Lab at Northern Arizona University and Associate Professor of Anthropology let at presentation and Q&A session entitled, “Increasing readiness for rapid research: Lessons from Covid-19.”

(2)   Broaden collaborations:

 

The second day of the workshop was a capacity-building/brainstorming day, beginning with a presentation from NAU’s Office of Sponsored projects. We then continued with breakout sessions aimed at hypothesis development. The workshop concluded with lessons learned and listing of specific goals for participants.

Project Outcomes:

The workshop had 13 attendees from four different departments, four invited speakers, and a presentation from NAU’s Office of Sponsored projects. Faculty from social science disciplines across the institution attended the workshop, including several members from the Economic Policy Institute, the Director of NAU’s Center for American Indian Economic Development, four researchers from NAU’s W.A. Franke College of Business spanning Assistant, Associate, and Full Professor rankings, one Assistant Professor of Sociology, and two Anthropology faculty. While all attendees had some experience collaborating across disciplines, a new and notable collaboration began between Economics and Anthropology, spurred by the exceptional presentation from Dr. Lisa Hardy. Attendees from NAU’s Economic Policy Institute provided positive and enthusiastic feedback that the workshop provided them with much needed training and support to submit external grant proposals, especially those supporting economic development in Native American communities surrounding NAU. One year after the meeting, several of the attendees are continuing to explore collaborations and submit proposals for external funding. Three workshop attendees successfully submitted external grant proposals, with three of the proposals awarded funding.
